Description: Dome-shaped weight carved from dark grey hard stone, likely basalt; carinated dome type with well-defined edge; of truncated conical shape, with flat base and convex top; smoothed surface; complete.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Oriental Institute, University of Chicago. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Cupcake-shaped weights, especially the one made out of basalt, are the most common type found in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, Pl. XXIII, “domed” type), and elsewhere in Egypt (Cour-Marty 1990, 25-26, fig. 4, fig. 13). They start to be particularly popular with the Late Period, even though they do appear with the Ramesside Period (Cour-Marty 1990, 25-26, fig. 26). Such type is especially associated to the Egyptian standard deben-kedet (usually around 90-95 g and 9-9,5 g for this type) and their multiples or sub-multiples (Cour-Marty 1990, 20, 25, fig. 22-24). This specimen could correspond to a fifth of a kedet, a common weight for the cupcake weights and related types (Cour-Marty 1990, 24). Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1989. Les poids dans l’Égypte ancienne, Vols. 1-3 [unpublished thesis, microform], Paris. Cour-Marty, M.-A. 1990, 'Les poids égyptiens, de précieux jalons archéologiques', Cahier de Recherches de l'Institut de Papyrologie et d'Egyptologie de Lille 12, 17-55. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, 69-87, pl. XXI-XXIV. Petrie, W. M. F. 1926, Ancient Weights and Measures Illustrated by the Egyptian Collection in University College, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (VA.058)
